title: Why are some people unemployed? - Quora

response.answer_text: Maybe all of those things. Plus there will always be a small core of people who don't want a job, or have mental health issues or substance abuse issues. Mental health problems are a major reason why some people are not only unemployed, but also homeless. This is something that could happen to anyone anytime; most people who develop mental illnesses can be helped, but there are some who are very difficult to help. There are also many people who have a problem not severe enough to stop them functioning, but that makes it hard for them to get a job. Some people just can't face the 9 till 5. I'm guessing most unemployed people don't have any particular issues, but they get discouraged about finding work and the jobs they have the skills to do are not ones they especially feel like doing. Some people can learn new skills easily, but others feel like it's an impossible task. One thing schools could really do to help is to teach people how to set up their own businesses, whether online or in real life. A business isn't necessarily a huge undertaking where you draw up a business plan and find investors. It can just be a little thing where you engage in some kind of trade for cash. I don't think schools really teach this at all. Partly this must be because most teachers don't have the right kind of experience to pass on. Yet if you look at statistics, an awful lot of people actually work for themselves or for a family business. Some say schools are geared towards producing "drones" that work endlessly and unthinkingly for other people. I wonder if there isn't a grain of truth in that. Of course, not everyone comes out of school wanting to be a "drone", but they don't necessarily know what else to do. When you look at a typical school day, it consists basically in doing what you're told all day, learning stuff that often does not have an immediate practical application. This trains people to work in offices or factories, but doesn't train them to run their own business. This means that anyone who doesn't want to work for others, faces an immense psychological barrier in working for themselves. Nothing in school, probably not even business studies classes, prepares them for it. School trains us to be subservient, not to think for ourselves.
